A brand-new addition to the Collectible Card Game genre that showcases a wave-focused game play instead of the AI-focused standard"

Game Overview
This game features a wave-focused

and maximum cards in hand" at the start of each stage up to "the cards available for their use".

There are "class-specific" and also "common cards" which gives you the freedom to make a more flexible and versatile adjustment that matches your play style.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is not meant to be a technical review (as I'm a beginner with Trading Card Games) but only an effort to help pushing this game out of Early Access by giving Developers a thumbs up and recommending PANOPTES to new potential gamers.

The game is missions based (I read there are more than 50 to be played right now and new content is being added with constant updates); there are 3 characters (Hunter, Occultist and Scientist): each one has their own cards and can access some common cards from the Arsenal. When you complete a quest you get reward points and you can buy booster of cards from the Store; if you're not happy with some of the cards you got from boosters, you can sell them and craft new ones with the resulting credits.

I'm having some difficulties with Hard" quests
date: not only because they are meant to be difficult but also because of luck; yes
recommended: when drawing cards from the deck
hoursPlayed: luck plays a very important role
voteText: like you'll die several times when
votesHelpful: you're not getting Medikits in time to heal yourself (deck has 30 cards and you can have max 2 cards of the same type
votesTotal: so there are only 2 Medikits max - there are some other healing cards but they are not sufficient on their own).\nSolution for success is going to the Arsenal and build a new deck (or modify it) until you get the proper cards for the current quest you're playing. There are several different aspects to take into account while fighting
votesFunny: starting from the type of cards you're going to use
commentsCount: effects and conditions that are applied to them
column16: type of damage they inflict and monsters you're dealing with
column17: because each and every one of them is pretty much unique.\n\nSo
column18: I'm having quite a lot of fun playing PANOPTES and feel like recommending it with flying colors."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

PANOPTES:
~~~~~~~~~

You are part of an organisation which is known as “The Club”; an organisation which operates totally off-the-books. Better that way, as you will fight against Mythical Monsters, Aliens and more.

PANOPTES is a TCG driven story where you have to engage in combat against enemies using a deck of cards. In this early access, you will be playing 3 types of characters: Hunters, Scientists and Occultists. Each of these types have they own abilities and basic deck of cards. The basic deck of cards (30 cards per deck) for the Hunters will have more common weapons, cards and tools. The Occultists, in comparison, will have more magic cards and the scientists will have a balance of the two.

Combat-wise, it is simple to understand how it works. You have a deck of 30 cards at your disposal. You can draw or see a maximum of 5 cards at any given time. You might fight 1 wave of enemies (it could be 1 enemy in one wave) or several with a single deck of cards. Can be tricky at times. Each card will use a specific number of energy points to use against your foe. Remember that each time you draw a card from the deck, it will cost you 1 energy point and at the start of each turn you will have 5 energy points at your disposition. Cards like the Adrenaline Injection will give you an extra energy point but only for a minimum of turns. If you win the battle, you will be given a couple of new cards and reward points which you can use to purchase a booster pack at the store to help you to unlock new cards (you might not gain any new cards). Booster packs are not cheap; you will need 600 points to purchase a booster with 5 extra cards in it, and 7900 points for a booster which includes 75 cards in this current version.

The graphics component for this genre of game is very good and the audio creates very suspenseful atmosphere. I do like the information tab, you will get information about your team, missions, factions and more.

This is a solid early access as far as I am concerned and I look forward to seeing updates.

Positives:
~~~~~~~

-	Audio gives you an atmosphere of suspense
-	Nice content for an early access
-	Nice graphics for its genre

Negatives:
~~~~~~~~

-	No trading cards

I really believe this game has great potential even if winning a battle relies heavily on drawing the right card at the right time.

7/10 (early access score)

Key provided by developer/publisher for review purposes. Any opinions expressed are entirely my own!

FOLLOW THE CPT FROGGY CURATOR PAGE HERE

reviewText:
Early Access Review

When it comes to TCGs I'm always a little cautious as getting the balance right with cards and creating a TCG that has good synergy is very difficult but I think PANOPTES actually hits the nail on the head.

PANOPTES focuses on story and PVE which is a welcome break from the usual PVP that TGCs focus on. I've enjoyed a lot of Magic: The Gathering and Hearthstone in the past so I'm not new to this genre but I do feel PANOPTES touches on something a little different.
Story-wise you are part of 'The Club' which seems to be an organization that hunts monsters and other supernatural beings in a world where most people try to turn a blind eye. Your aim is to rid the world of these evils and protect those who can't protect themselves.

For those of you who haven't played this style of game before the aim is to build your own deck from three classes (Scientist, Occultist and Hunter) each with their own class specific cards and play-styles, to defeat waves of enemies per mission. Each class has their own strengths: Hunter is more weapon based whereas Occultist focuses on magic and spells, and each requires different strategy. Each deck is made up of 30 cards which are drawn at random and it is with these cards you must defeat your foes each mission. Drawing and playing cards uses something called Energy which replenishes itself at the start of each turn. Enemies do not have energy and instead only attack with their monsters each turn rather than playing any new cards. Once you complete a mission you are rewarded with new cards and some in game points which can be used to buy booster packs. These seem to range from 600 to 8000 points, 600 point packs containing 5 cards and 7900 point packs containing 75 cards.
The fact that you can unlock new cards for your decks gives this game plenty of re-playability BUT I would love to see card trading with other players introduced. Despite the fact that the game is PVE I think it'd add a strong community within the game which I feel is very important in TCGs.

Creating a deck is already very fun and a little challenging. There is a great amount of cards currently and as I said before, the classes add even more choice and let you play your way. Where PANOPTES focuses on PVE this allows you to build your decks how YOU want to play rather than having to build decks to counter commonly used overpowered decks like you do when you play PVP TCGs which is a relief. It makes the game much more engaging and way more enjoyable to play on your own terms.

Another thing I really like about PANOPTES, and which is often overlooked, is the graphics. The art style is very clean and all the cards are very detailed. Usually in pre-aplha games there is a lot of placeholder art but I feel the artists put a lot of time into creating something amazing from the start. I enjoyed just browsing the cards.

There ARE balance issues with some of the cards but this is being routinely worked on so do expect some cards to be nerfed and others to be buffed whilst the development is going on but that is just a part of the Early Access process.

I think that PANOPTES is a very strong contender in the TCG arena despite the fact that it's still in Pre-Alpha Early Access. In fact I'm surprised this is even considered pre-alpha. There is plenty of content to keep you going through development and the developers seem engaged with the community and are pushing out updates once a month on average.
I am very excited to see what becomes of PANOPTES because it already is a fantastic addition to the TCG genre.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Good game with plenty of content already. It's got some pretty challenging fights in it, so not for casual players.

PROS:

Good, consistant, artwork throughout. Cards are nicely illustrated, with the techno/magic world being well represented.

Decent ambient music and incidental sounds.

Three characters with three different basic playstyles. Each can be heavily tailored to deal with different threats and synergize decks for rushing, DOTs etc. Plenty of scope for customisation.

A pretty impressive amount of cards already. You start with a basic set for each character, and unlock new cards by completing missions or buying boosters with in-game currency. There are NO MICROTRANSACTIONS :D

Genuinely tough fights in places. They need a customised deck and a proper strategy to beat.


CONS:

The UI is clearly a work in progress. It's fully functional but bare bones at the moment. It's also a little dry"
date: without much feedback when card interactions happen.\n\nLack of mouse-over text. All the rules and card effects are explained in the game
hoursPlayed: if you want to find out what
voteText: for example
helpfulPercent: the "indomitable" effect does on a monster card
votesHelpful: you'll have to go through quite a few clicks to get there.\n\nWall of text cards. Some of the boss cards have a ton of effects and conditions on them
votesTotal: which can be a little hard to parse. I'd like to see these eventually condensed down to mouse-over hyperlinks
votesFunny: which bring up what each effect does as you hover over it.\n\nLack of damage/effect predictions. Some cards do things like "Damage = 3 +number of spell cards in the card graveyard"
column16: you have to manually go into the graveyard and count the spell cards. Things like this should be automated
column17: and hopefully will be. I'd also like to see what the potential effects of a selected card will be on enemies as I hover over them.\n\nThat's it so far. I'm on mission 37 at the time of writing
column18: and I definitely feel like I've got my money's worth so far. Looking forward to any improvements and extra content.\n"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Panoptes is a truly engaging game. It's classified as a horror Trading Card Game (TCG) and takes a Player vs Environment (PvE) approach as opposed to the more common Player vs Player (PvP) approach usually seen in this type of game.

Graphically, the game is unexpectedly beautiful. The artwork is unique and has a dark urban fantasy vibe to it. The soundtrack actually enhances this mood and creates a suspenseful experience.

The story itself is also engaging, and that's very unique to this style of game where storyline is generally minimal. The controls are very easy to master, but keep in mind that this is a game that doesn't offer controller support. It's strictly mouse and keyboard functionality.

Gameplay is also fully functional and easy to learn, even if you've never played a game of this type before. The premise for this game is that you're an agent of an organization called The Club
date: and your purpose is to vanquish mythological and supernatural creatures.\n\nGame objectives are met through the drawing and playing of cards, and deckbuilding is central to the game, as is typical with this genre. There's no mana, but instead energy" comes into play
recommended: and it is spent and regained through the course of gameplay.\n\nThe game has more than 50 different missions and three character classes: Scientist
voteText: and Hunter. Each class will have cards that are specific to the class while other cards are universal. Points are awarded for completing missions successfully
helpfulPercent:
and those points are then used to obtain additional cards.

The ability to customize your deck and playthrough multiple times with different character classes means that this game has a great deal of replayability.

There are just two Steam achievements at this point and no Steam cards
votesHelpful: but this game is in the Early Access stage
votesTotal: so it's entirely possible that we will see expansions to game content and extras in the near future.\n\nI didn't experience any game crashes or game-breaking bugs
votesFunny: and overall the game feels and functions like a fully finished product. I'm actually very amazed at the overall package and excited to see what the developers will consider to be the finished version.\n\nI recommend this game very highly to any fan of TCG and CCG games
commentsCount: as well as those who appreciate a darker gaming atmosphere.\n\n*This review is featured on the curator page of Review Experts."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Card games have been all of the rage what with all of the success enjoyed by Magic the Gathering and more so on PC with Blizzard’s Hearthstone. I, myself, have to admit to more than a little bit of addiction to Hearthstone. While I don’t quite have every card in the game or reached legendary status I have played countless hours in the game. Therefore, I do find it interesting when a new entry is added to the Steam catalogue. Games such as Hand of Fate and Card City Nights have seen significant playtime on my account. This time it is Suricate Games with their first foray onto the Steam platform with PANOPTES.

It’s currently in an early alpha pre-release stage but I believe that Suricate Games got it right with releasing it onto Steam now. The base game is already in a very playable state meaning that players will be able to begin to experience what the entire game is like when it’s all finalized by their estimated date of the second half of the year. The basic mechanics are similar to the genre. You get a few cards to start off with, some action points to play them and a draw pile. Unlike other games that I’ve played a player can use an action point to draw from their draw pile. The cards have different properties that are either weapons, heals or serve utility purposes. The AI, unlike other card games, come in the form of waves. In the quests that I played through the first wave came with two mobs, the middle one was a loner, a third was stronger than the first and you either finish after three or there can be even longer waves.

The story hasn’t been fleshed out yet so it’s unfair to delve much deeper there. Thus far the graphics are more than suitable and the sound was suffice. These are things that could all change as the development moves closer to final release.

What I did play was definitely enjoyable and is a game that I cannot wait to come back to – being that I am a card game addict. So that’s who I can recommend it to. If you’ve ever wanted to provide some input into the making of a card game, want to support something that could be very, very good from its alpha stage then do get in on PANOPTES.

Hello , I played in early access and finished the game.
It's a very fun game with beautiful polish in gameplay, music and somewhat esthetic design (card icon, ui ). Enjoyed every bit of it, especially unpacking those juicy 15x booster packs. I hope there's more missions or new random mission/reward to increase replayability.

Deck managements is very simple to use ; hard encounters will give you a tough challlenge if you don't experiment with decking.

This is a must-have game for every RPG / trading card connaisseur.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm going to preface this. I did refund the game.

That being said it isn't a terrible game. The mechanics are solid and I didn't encounter any bugs.
However for a game that touts itself as story driven I felt completely unengaged. The narrative was stilted and fragmented and the delivery lacking.

If you want a basic decent card game, go for it. It's got that for sure. The gameplay is fun enough. If you are looking for a story driven game I'd advise waiting. I'm keeping it on my follow list and may come back as development goes along if I like what I see.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I’m glad to see this amazing story driven trading card game available on Steam. In comparison to the Pre Alpha Demo I’ve played the Early Access has shown great progression including multiple new features. I played the pre alpha demo on my channel a while back and instantly fell in love with the concept, you don’t see to many card games that are story driven and have a horror aspect to it. What makes it stand out so much is the level of the detail in the artwork, it’s comparable to Magic The Gathering. The music truly captures you, making you realize you are in complete isolation having to complete your mission of taking on your enemies. I also noticed they added quite a bit of lore to the background of the organization and it’s members which is an interesting read. My only gripe with the game at the moment is it needs more animations in terms of when the cards are in effect. I also hope to see future instalments of when hovering over the card the symbols are explained without going to the clue mark at the top of the screen. Overall I love the game and will keep supporting it as it progresses through many changes to come, I recommend it to anyone who loves card games that contain horror elements, be apart of The Club and take down these abominations!

I've also made a Let's Play of the first mission and a general introduction about the features of the game if you would like to check it out!

Link to the Let's Play: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=62u0dwsEEeE

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I started playing after update zero, the balance patch on Jan 27th and I consider it money well-spent at this point in time. I'm some 30 odd missions into the campaign, and thoroughly enjoying the difficulty level.

This is a game that requires deck-building strategy, and you don't always figure out what you need till you've taken a beating, and then it may still take a few attempts to get a workable combo.

I also appreciate that the variety in the missions (and enemies) means you're using different classes and cards along the way. So when you do unlock some booster packs it's more fun than in some other CCGs where it's likely that a bunch of the cards won't see any real play.
